Summary I am a 30-year veteran of the Tele/Data/Cellular Communication industry. I have a proven track record of being successful at every endeavor I have undertaken. I currently hold one of the most coveted positions within Cisco (CAP Director). During critical crisis situations, my position requires not only a quick thinker, but a person that can put together a game-plan in a very short amount that addresses critical issues in a timely manner. My experience in the field and in a corporate, environment affords me the experience to view issues from all perspectives. As my resume indicates I built my career being put into difficult on-site situations where the mission was deemed hopeless. In all those situations, I not only resolved the conflict, but put my company in a better position with the customer than it was found. I am a dedicated self-motivated overachiever with a proven track record of success in everything's challenge I have undertaken. I simply don’t know how to fail! 
 
One should be aware I have successfully worn every technical hat conceivable at Cisco and at every level of engagement. During my tenor in the technological world, I have been responsible for millions of dollars in revenue world-wide and contributed to stabilize countless critical situations resulting in relationships being rescued and loyalty reinstated, or established. During vital network instability, communication is the key in order to maintain a sense of calm and allow clear concise decisions to be made. I excelled at both countless times with some of the largest companies around the world. During my tenor as a Trials Engineering, I successfully conducted competitive bake-offs against Cisco’s biggest competitors, traveling across the globe representing Cisco and its products to all the major Telco’s around the globe. Experience Critical Accounts Director Cisco April 2009  – Present (6 years 5 months) Lake Tapps, Washington In 2009, I made the decision to hang up my technical hat and transitioned into a Critical Account Director in Customer Assurance. This position is one of the most coveted and highest profile positions within Cisco, as we are extensions of John Chambers’ (CEO) office. CAP Managers have unfettered access to the resources of Cisco to become the ultimate customer advocate. CAP is engaged when customer situations are dire, or all but lost. Our job is to engage in the Executive level and do what it takes to assess and resolve the situation. This might involve contract/legal issues, technical challenges, SLA violations, delayed product/feature enhancements, Healthcare HIPPA/HITECH FDA violations, etc. The goal is to quickly assess critical situations, construct a plan of attack, assemble a cross-functional team, and communicate status with Cisco and Customer Executives, while maintaining a fiduciary accountability. Engagements are worked concurrently with multiple accounts, and failure is not an option. Villanova University Six Sigma Green Belt,  Six Sigma , A 2014  – 2014 Six Sigma seeks to improve the quality of process outputs by identifying and removing the causes of defects (errors) and minimizing variability in manufacturing and business processes. It uses a set of quality management methods, including statistical methods, and creates a special infrastructure of people within the organization ("Champions", "Black Belts", "Green Belts", "Yellow Belts", etc.) who are experts in these methods. Each Six Sigma project carried out within an organization follows a defined sequence of steps and has quantified value targets, for example: reduce process cycle time, reduce pollution, reduce costs, increase customer satisfaction, and increase profits. These are also core to principles of Total Quality Management (TQM) as described by Peter Drucker and Tom Peters (particularly in his book "The Pursuit of Excellence" in which he refers to the Motorola six sigma principles). These are also core to principles of Total Quality Management (TQM) as described by Peter Drucker and Tom Peters (particularly in his book "The Pursuit of Excellence" in which he refers to the Motorola six sigma principles).
